history.content:
No, but please do yourself a favor by learning linear algebra really well, like to the point that it feels like high school algebra to you (if you want to just focus on learning the optimization parts of the course). Especially, SVD, PCA, diagonalization, symmetric matrices, column operations, matrix operations.

-----

Would add that 54 + 16A is probably not a reasonable level of lin. alg. for 127; 110 + 16AB is optimal. Don't feel like you need to rush into 127; if you have to spend most of your time in the class trying to learn lin. alg. rather than optimization theory, what was the point of taking 127?

----

I think the best preparation is EE16A+EE16B. Found it pretty easy to digest the materials in EE127. If you think you have a good self-study ability I would recommend Gibert Strang's Linear Algebra Tutorial on MIT OCW.

https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/mathematics/18-06-linear-algebra-spring-2010/index.htm

----

Workload-wise, I honestly wouldn't take 127+170+188. It seems like unnecessary amount of work for one semester, since if you're trying to "rush" through these classes to be prepared for 189/ML/AI research, then it's likely taking this workload will leave you underprepared anyway (not enough time to fully think about/understand the material imo). That's just my 2 cents.

No, but please do yourself a favor by learning linear algebra really well. Esp, SVD, PCA, diagonalization, symmetric matrices, column operations, matrix operations.

16A+16B+70, along with Math 53, are of course, the recommended background. 16AB for the linear-algebraic content and modeling philosophy, with the rigor and proof dimensions  of 70, and the multivariate calculus from 53 finishing out the expected background. However, *because* 127 is also 227A and is also aimed at graduate students coming from elsewhere who might not have the level of linear algebra and modeling philosophy that EE16AB provide at Berkeley, 127 can be understandable with only the level of knowledge from say, Math 54. However, this is typically done by implicitly leaning on the maturity that such students are expected to bring.

The importance of the maturity dimension is what many undergrad students seem to consistently underestimate. 127 is a proper entry-level upper-division course if you have the right material background (16A, 16B, 70's maturity, Math 53, and the programming maturity from the rest of the lower division). A student will work hard, have their linear algebra, vector calculus, and proof/derivation abilities greatly strengthened along the way, and grow in both maturity and in an understanding of optimization. Such students will lean on what they learned in the lower division to achieve this.  Alternatively, if a student has gaps in their material background, but already has more advanced maturity, then they can lean on this maturity and pick up the gaps in their background as things are reviewed in 127. They will also work hard, but this will be because they are going to have to learn more stuff. A student who has neither the right background nor the extra maturity is simply asking for pain.

Hello! I'm just wondering if EE16B is a hard prerequisite for EECS127? I've already taken Math 54 and will have finished EE16A this semester.

 

(also does EECS127, CS170, and CS188 sound like a manageable tech schedule for next semester)


Update: Thanks! I've also taken CS70, 61A/61B, another upper div, and (the equivalent of) Math 53; I'd also taken linear algebra before 54, so I'd like to think I have some level of mathematical maturity. I'll still be figuring out whether or not that schedule is manageable, but all the input is really appreciated ^-^
history.subject: EECS127 Prerequisites?
